sndlib.core.util
Class NetworkUtils

java.lang.Object
  sndlib.core.util.NetworkUtils

public class NetworkUtils
extends java.lang.Object

This class provides some commonly used utility methods on a Network (or rather a Problem).

Author:
Roman Klaehne

Method Detail

getLinksByIds

public static java.util.List<Link> getLinksByIds(java.util.List<java.lang.String> linkIds,
                                                 Network network)
Given a list of link ID's this method returns the corresponding Links in the specified network

If some link cannot be found in the network then this method returns null. If all links are found then the returned list will have the same order as the given one.

Parameters:
linkIds - the list of link ID's
network - the network in which the links are to be looked for
Returns:
a List of Links in the same order as the given List of link ID's; null if some link cannot be found

getMaxDemandValue

public static double getMaxDemandValue(Network network)
Calculates the maximal demand value over all demands contained in the given network.

Parameters:
network - the network
Returns:
the maximal demand value

getIncidentLinks

public static java.util.List<Link> getIncidentLinks(Node node,
                                                    Network network)
Determines all incident links of the given node.

A link is incident to a node if that node is either the link's source or the link's target node.
(link l incident to node n <=> l.source = n or l.target = n)

If no link is incident to the given node then this method returns an empty list.

Parameters:
node - the node
network - the network enclosing the node
Returns:
a List of the incident Links

getNodeInDegree

public static int getNodeInDegree(Node node,
                                  Problem problem)
Determines the in-degree of the given node.

If the given problem's LinkModel is DIRECTED then the in-degree of a node is the number of its incident links of which that node is the target.

If the LinkModel is not DIRECTED then there is no definite target node. Thus the in-degree of a node is simply the number of its incident links.

Parameters:
node - the node to calculate the in-degree for
problem - the problem around the node
Returns:
the in-degree of the given node

getNodeOutDegree

public static int getNodeOutDegree(Node node,
                                   Problem problem)
Determines the out-degree of the given node.

If the given problem's LinkModel is DIRECTED then the out-degree of a node is the number of its incident links of which that node is the source.

If the LinkModel is not DIRECTED then there is no definite source node. Thus the out-degree of a node is simply the number of its incident links.

Parameters:
node - the node to calculate the out-degree for
problem - the problem around the node
Returns:
the out-degree of the given node

getNodeDegree

public static int getNodeDegree(Node node,
                                Network network)
Determines the degree of the given node.

The degree of a given node is simply the number of its incident links. Therefore this method is the same as getIncidentLinks().size()

Parameters:
node - the node to calculate the degree for
network - the network of the node
Returns:
the degree of the given node

areParallel

public static boolean areParallel(Link l1,
                                  Link l2)
Tests whether the given two links are parallel.

Because no specific network model is took into account, parallel means either really parallel or anti-parallel (for the directed case).

Parameters:
l1 - the first link
l2 - the second link
Returns:
true if and only if the given two links are (anti-) parallel; false otherwise

areParallel

public static boolean areParallel(Demand d1,
                                  Demand d2)
Tests whether the given two demands are parallel.

Because no specific network model is took into account, parallel means either really parallel or anti-parallel (for the directed case).

Parameters:
d1 - the demand link
d2 - the demand link
Returns:
true if and only if the given two demands are (anti-) parallel; false otherwise

calculateDistanceInKms

public static double calculateDistanceInKms(Node n1,
                                            Node n2)
Calculates the real-world-distance of the given two nodes in kilometer.

This method assumes that the coordinates of the given nodes are geographical. If not, no warranty can be given on the result.

Parameters:
n1 - the source node
n2 - the target node
Returns:
the distance of the given two nodes in kilometer;
